I sorta became a vegetarian inadvertently for about 8 months around the end of 2021. I was diagnosed with high blood pressure around that time as a mid 20s guy. It runs in the family but I was a fat fuck and I'm determined not to die an early death. I took a look at my diet and decided I needed to eat more vegetables and less processed junk.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
The first 2 weeks were hell. I was fatigued, hungry and consistently wanted food. I wasn't satisfied. I started to realize that a bit of hunger was good for you, particularly if you want to lose weight. I decided on one cheat meal a week, and let me tell you that fast food was the best thing I've ever eaten. I then realized that fast food was an actual addictive substance. That's what I mean by sorta vegetarian, I'd eat a meat meal once a week. After those first 2 weeks I felt pretty damn good.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
Varied as much as possible. Salads, MANY vegetable soups over a small amount of rice, as much fresh vegetables as I could. Spaghetti squash is a fucking miracle food, I still eat it regularly. I'd get protein from beans and peanut butter.
>Did you need to take supplements?
I took protein powder a few times a week.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
Hell yea it is. Potatoes, celery, onions and carrots are dirt cheap (potatoes less so now adays). Started my own garden with other shit as a complete noob and made more than what it cost me. I'm excited to start it again this year. Fresh and canned vegetables are dirt cheap, not so much in the winter.

posts.com:
Was a vegetarian during my most of my teenage years up until I was about 17. I was also a vegetarian for 49 days due to the death of my grandmother.
It takes about a week or two of getting used to, but after that, as long as you have resolve, you shouldn’t have any issues. You can still eat cheese and eggs unless you’re a vegan, so you really can have the vast majority of dishes by substituting. As I get older I would eventually like to go back to vegetarianism just for general religious reasons. I usually plan all my meals for the week when I go grocery shopping, and as long as you’re not a vegan you won’t need supplementation.
Good go to dishes: pasta, burrata salads, bruscheta, homemade nachos, mapo doufu, various noodle dishes, eggplant in garlic sauce, xifan, scrambled eggs, bean soups, potatoes, the world is your (vegetarian) oyster.

I was vegetarian for ~4 years from 2015 to 2019. Currently I eat 95% vegetarian.

>How did it affect you?
No noticeable effect to be honest.
>What were your go to meals?
Stews with beans and various pasta meals.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
I didn't cut out eggs or dairy so I didn't really give a shit about that stuff.
>Did you need to take supplements?
No. One of the oat milks I regularly use in cooking is enriched with B12 as well so even if I for some reason decided to become a vegan I'd probably not have to take any.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
Yes.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships?
No, I don't give a shit if you eat meat. Some people found it quite provoking but not to a degree that I actually lost anyone close to me. Nowadays finding vegetarian or even vegan meals when eating out is really not a problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18836039
Whole-food plant-based for almost four years now.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
It made me conscious about what I eat and that led me to make a number of other lifestyle changes in the interest of my health and wellbeing, including quitting drinking, cutting out processed sugars and fats, and drinking tea. My health has improved greatly. My acne and asthma are gone. My mood and energy levels are much better, too. I can see myself being WFPB for the rest of my life.
>What were your go to meals?
I eat a lot of fresh fruit and steamed vegetables. I also make big smoothies with mango, strawberry, spinach, and dates. I love beans, chickpeas, and lentils, and I make a lot of MENA/Ethiopian dishes, like falafel or masir wat. I also eat a lot of edamame and tofu.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
I eat on impulse.
>Did you need to take supplements?
Yes, I take a multivitamin to make sure I get enough iodine, zinc, copper, vitamin D, and vitamin B12.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
Mine isn't, lol. I spend a lot on smoothie ingredients. But that doesn't mean a vegan diet can't be cheap and nutritious.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships? (Can't date a meat eater, couldn't eat out as much etc)
Carnies don't care that I'm vegan because I don't care if they eat meat or anything in front of me. I would prefer to date another WFPB vegan, though. Being vegan, especially WFPB, does make it much, much harder to go out spontaneously.

Are you thinking about making the leap, OP? I'd say just try it for two weeks and see how you feel.

Similar but not similar enough to be confused. Both are acidic and sweet, similar color (talking about the processed product, not the berries themselves).

The jam is fine and also traditional, but the fresh stirred ones are nicer for sure.

>>18849511
Here is the Escoffier recipe for sauce bigarade often served with duck:

For braised duck: Pass the braising fond, get rid of the fat (works best with one of those fat separators), reduce it. Per liter: The juice of 4 oranges (actually bitter oranges but hard to get) and 1 lemon. Also add 2 spoons of heavily blanched orange peels and 1 spoon of lemon peels cut in very fine stripes.
For poêleed duck: Same procedere but without reducing the fond as strong so it has to be lightly thickened with arrowroot (i guess you can substitute it with starch). Also per liter 20 g caramel deglaced with 1 1/2 Tablespoons of vinegar.

I just use the second recipe for every cooking method. Also never use more peels than the recipe calls for. I made the mistake once and the sauce tasted and smelled pretty unpleasantly. For sautedduck breast i make the sauce on side with additional duck or veal fond as i got no braising liquid or drippings from that method.
